id.desc: Component ID, not specified by default. If specified, it can be used to refer the component in option or API.

name.desc: Series name used for displaying in [tooltip](~tooltip) and filtering with [legend](~legend), or updating data and configuration with `setOption`.

colorBy.desc:
> Since `v5.2.0`



The policy to take color from [option.color](~color). Valid values:

+ `'series'`: assigns the colors in the palette by series, so that all data in the same series are in the same color;
+ `'data'`: assigns colors in the palette according to data items, with each data item using a different color.

coordinateSystem.desc:
The coordinate used in the series, whose options are:




+ `'cartesian2d'`

Use a two-dimensional rectangular coordinate (also known as Cartesian coordinate), with [xAxisIndex](~series-lines.xAxisIndex) and [yAxisIndex](~series-lines.yAxisIndex) to assign the corresponding axis component.





+ `'geo'`

Use geographic coordinate, with [geoIndex](~series-lines.geoIndex) to assign the corresponding geographic coordinate components.

xAxisIndex.desc: Index of [x axis](~xAxis) to combine with, which is  useful for multiple x axes in one chart.

yAxisIndex.desc: Index of [y axis](~yAxis) to combine with, which is  useful for multiple y axes in one chart.

geoIndex.desc: Index of [geographic coordinate](~geo) to combine with, which is useful for multiple geographic axes in one chart.

polyline.desc:
If draw as a polyline.

Default to be `false`. Can only draw a two end straight line.

If it is set true, [data.coords](~series-lines.data.coords) can have more than two coord to draw a polyline. It is useful when visualizing GPS track data. See example [lines-bus](lines-bmap-bus).

effect.desc:
The setting about the special effects of lines.


**Tips: **All the graphs with trail effect should be put on a individual layer, which means that [zlevel](~series-lines.zlevel) need to be different with others. And the animation ([animation](~series-lines.animation): false)  of this layer is suggested to be turned off at the meanwhile. Otherwise, other graphic elements in other series and the [label](~series-lines.label) of animation would produce unnecessary ghosts.

effect.period.desc: The duration of special effect, which unit is second.

effect.delay.desc: Effect animation delay. Can be number or callback function.

effect.constantSpeed.desc: If symbol movement of special effect has a constant speed, which unit is pixel per second. [period](~series-lines.effect.period) will be ignored if `constantSpeed` is larger than 0.

effect.symbol.desc:
The symbol of special effect.



Icon types provided by ECharts includes



`'circle'`, `'rect'`, `'roundRect'`, `'triangle'`, `'diamond'`, `'pin'`, `'arrow'`, `'none'`







It can be set to an image with `'image://url'` , in which URL is the link to an image, or `dataURI` of an image.


An image URL example:

```
'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
```

A `dataURI` example:

```
'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
```



Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via `'path://'` in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData) for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

```
'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
```











The above example uses a custom path of plane shape.

**Tip:** Ahe angle of symbol changes as the tangent of track changes. If you use a custom path, you should make sure that the path shape are upward oriented. It would ensure that the symbol will always move toward the right moving direction when the symbol moves along the track.

effect.symbolSize.desc: The symbol size of special effect, which could be set as single number such as `10`. What's more, arrays could be used to decribe the width and height respectively. For instance, `[20, 10]` indicates `20` for width and  `10` for height.

effect.color.desc: The color of special effect symbol, which defaults to be same with [lineStyle.color](~series-lines.lineStyle.color).

effect.trailLength.desc: The length of trail of special effect.  The values from 0 to 1 could be set. Trail would be longer as the the value becomes larger.

effect.loop.desc: Whether to loop the special effect animation.

large.desc:
Whether to enable the optimization of large-scale lines graph. It could be enabled when there is a particularly large number of data(>=5k) .

After being enabled, [largeThreshold](~series-lines.largeThreshold) can be used to indicate the minimum number for turning on the optimization.

The style of a single data item can't be customized

largeThreshold.desc: The threshold enabling the drawing optimization.

symbol.desc: Symbol type at the two ends of the line. It can be an array for two ends, or assigned seperately. See [data.symbol](~series-line.markLine.data.0.symbol) for more format information.

symbolSize.desc:
Symbol size at the two ends of the line. It can be an array for two ends, or assigned seperately.

**Attention: ** You cannot assgin width and height seperately as normal `symbolSize`.

lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color. Color is taken from [option.color Palette](~color) by default.


Supports callback functions, in the form of:
```js
(params: Object) => Color
```
Input parameters are `seriesIndex`, `dataIndex`, `data`, `value`, and etc. of data item.




> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

lineStyle.type.desc:
line type.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`dashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

type: [5, 10],

dashOffset: 5
}
```

lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`type`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

lineStyle.cap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

lineStyle.join.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`miterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`join`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

lineStyle.curveness.desc: The curveness of edge. The values from 0 to 1 could be set. The curveness would be larger as the the value becomes larger.

label.desc: Label settings. Does not work when [polyline](~series-lines.polyline) is `true`.

label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment.

label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

label.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

label.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

label.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

label.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`textBorderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}
```

label.textBorderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`textBorderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

label.textShadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text itself.

label.textShadowBlur.desc: Shadow blue of the text itself.

label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

label.rich.<style_name>.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment.

label.rich.<style_name>.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

label.rich.<style_name>.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:

+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

`borderType`

label.rich.<style_name>.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

label.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

label.rich.<style_name>.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

label.rich.<style_name>.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

label.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

label.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

label.rich.<style_name>.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

label.rich.<style_name>.textBorderType.desc:


label.rich.<style_name>.textBorderDashOf.desc:

`textBorderType`

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

label.rich.<style_name>.textShadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text itself.

label.rich.<style_name>.textShadowBlur.desc: Shadow blue of the text itself.

label.rich.<style_name>.textShadowOffset.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

labelLayout.hideOverlap.desc:
If hide the overlapped labels.

The following example shows how to hide the overlapped labels in graph automatically when zooming.

~[600x400](graph-label-overlap&edit=1&reset=1)

labelLayout.moveOverlap.desc:
If move the overlapped labels to avoid overlapping.

Currently supported configurations:

+ `'shiftX'` Place the labels on horizontal direction sequencely, used when aligned horizontally.
+ `'shiftY'` Place the labels on vertial direction sequencely, used when aligned vertically.

The following example shows how to use `moverOverlap: 'shiftY'` to place the labels aligned vertically.

~[600x400](scatter-label-align-right&edit=1&reset=1)

labelLayout.x.desc: The x position of the label. Support absolute pixel values ​​or relative values ​​such as `'20%'`.

labelLayout.y.desc: The y position of the label. Support absolute pixel values ​​or relative values ​​such as `'20%'`.

labelLayout.dx.desc: The pixel offset of the label in the x direction. Can be used with `x`.

labelLayout.dy.desc: The pixel offset of the label in the y direction. Can be used with `y`

labelLayout.width.desc: The width of displayed label. Can be used with `overflow` to constraint the label in a fixed width

labelLayout.height.desc: The height of displayed label. Can be used with `lineOverflow` to constraint the label in a fixed height.

labelLayout.align.desc: The horizontal alignment of the label. Can be `'left'`, `'center'`, `'right'`.

labelLayout.verticalAlign.desc: The vertical alignment of the label. Can be `'top'`, `'middle'`, `'bottom'`.

labelLayout.fontSize.desc: The text size of the label.

labelLayout.draggable.desc: Whether to allow the user to adjust the position by dragging.

labelLayout.labelLinePoints.desc:
The array of the three points of the label guide line. The format is:

```js
[[x, y], [x, y], [x, y]]
```

It is often used in pie charts to fine-tune the guide line that has been calculated. Usually not recommended to set it in other situations.

emphasis.focus.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`




When the data is highlighted, whether to fade out of other data to focus the highlighted. The following configurations are supported:

+ `'none'` Do not fade out other data, it's by default.
+ `'self'` Only focus (not fade out) the element of the currently highlighted data.


+ `'series'` Focus on all elements of the series which the currently highlighted data belongs to.




**Example: **


```js
emphasis: {
focus: 'series',
blurScope: 'coordinateSystem'
}
```

~[600x400](bar-y-category-stack&reset=1&edit=1)

emphasis.blurScope.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`



The range of fade out when `focus` is enabled. Support the following configurations

+ `'coordinateSystem'`
+ `'series'`
+ `'global'`

emphasis.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color. Can set to `'inherit'` in the `emphasis` state to disable color highlight.





> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

emphasis.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`dashOffset`

For example：
```js

dashOffset: 5
```

Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

emphasis.lineStyle.join.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`miterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

emphasis.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

emphasis.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

emphasis.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.borderC.desc: Border color of the text fragment.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.borderW.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.borderT.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.borderD.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.borderR.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowC.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowB.desc: Show blur of the text block.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowO.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.textBor.desc: Storke line width of the text.

Stroke line type of the text.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`textBorderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}
```

> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`textBorderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.textSha.desc: Shadow color of the text itself.
Shadow blue of the text itself.
Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

blur.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`



Configurations of blur state. Available when [emphasis.focus](~series-lines.emphasis.focus) is set.

blur.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color. Can set to `'inherit'` in the `emphasis` state to disable color highlight.





> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

blur.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`dashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

type: [5, 10],

dashOffset: 5
}
```

blur.lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`type`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

blur.lineStyle.cap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

blur.lineStyle.join.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`miterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

blur.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`join`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

blur.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

blur.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

blur.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

blur.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

blur.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

Besides, it can be set to `'single'` or `'multiple'`, for single selection and multiple selections.

progressive.desc:
`progressive` specifies the amount of graphic elements that can be rendered within a frame (about 16ms) if "progressive rendering" enabled.

When data amount is from thousand to more than 10 million, it will take too long time to render all of the graphic elements. Since ECharts 4, "progressive rendering" is supported in its workflow, which processes and renders data chunk by chunk alone with each frame, avoiding to block the UI thread of the browser.

Set `progressive: 0` to disable progressive permanently. By default, progressive is auto-enabled when data amount is bigger than `progressiveThreshold`.

progressiveThreshold.desc: If current data amount is over the threshold, "progressive rendering" is enabled.

dataGroupId.desc:
A groupID common to all data in the series. the groupID will be used to classify the data and determine how merge and split animations are performed in the universal transition animation.

If you are using the [dataset](~dataset) component to represent the data, it is recommended to use `encode.itemGroupID` to specify which dimension is encoded as the groupID.

data.groupId.desc: The groupID of this data item. groupID will be used to classify the data.

data.coords.desc: An array includes two ore more than two coordinates. Each coordinate could be `[x, y]` in [rectangular coordinate](~grid) and `[lng, lat]` in [geographic coordinate](~geo).

data.lineStyle.desc: The line style of this data item.

data.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.





> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

data.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`dashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

type: [5, 10],

dashOffset: 5
}
```

data.lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`type`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

data.lineStyle.cap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

data.lineStyle.join.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`miterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

data.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`join`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

data.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

data.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

data.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

data.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

data.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

data.lineStyle.curveness.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

data.label.desc: Label of a single line. Available when [polyline](~series-lines.polyline) is not `true`.

data.label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment.

data.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

data.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

data.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

data.label.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

data.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

data.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

data.label.lineOverflow.desc:

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

data.blur.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

data.blur.label.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

data.blur.label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

data.blur.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

data.blur.label.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

data.blur.label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

data.blur.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

data.blur.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

data.blur.label.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

data.blur.label.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`textBorderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}
```

data.blur.label.textBorderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`textBorderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

data.blur.label.textShadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text itself.

data.blur.label.textShadowBlur.desc: Shadow blue of the text itself.

data.blur.label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

data.blur.label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

data.blur.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

data.blur.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

data.blur.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

data.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.paddin.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

data.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.shadow.desc: Shadow color of the text block.
Show blur of the text block.
Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

data.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

data.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

data.select.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color. Can set to `'inherit'` in the `emphasis` state to disable color highlight.





> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

data.select.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`dashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

type: [5, 10],

dashOffset: 5
}
```

data.select.lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`type`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

data.select.lineStyle.cap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

data.select.lineStyle.join.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`miterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

data.select.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`join`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

data.select.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

data.select.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

data.select.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

data.select.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

data.select.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markPoint.symbol.desc:
Symbol of .



Icon types provided by ECharts includes



`'circle'`, `'rect'`, `'roundRect'`, `'triangle'`, `'diamond'`, `'pin'`, `'arrow'`, `'none'`







It can be set to an image with `'image://url'` , in which URL is the link to an image, or `dataURI` of an image.


An image URL example:

```
'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
```

A `dataURI` example:

```
'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
```



Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via `'path://'` in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData) for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

```
'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
```












If symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:
```js
(value: Array|number, params: Object) => string
```
The first parameter `value` is the value in [data](~series-lines.data), and the second parameter `params` is the rest parameters of data item.

markPoint.symbolSize.desc:
symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like `10`, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, `[20, 10]` means symbol width is `20`, and height is`10`.


If size of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:
```js
(value: Array|number, params: Object) => number|Array
```
The first parameter `value` is the value in [data](~series-lines.data), and the second parameter `params` is the rest parameters of data item.

markPoint.symbolRotate.desc:
Rotate degree of  symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when `symbol` is set to be `'arrow'` in `markLine`, `symbolRotate` value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.


If rotation of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:
```js
(value: Array|number, params: Object) => number
```
The first parameter `value` is the value in [data](~series-lines.data), and the second parameter `params` is the rest parameters of data item.
> Callback is supported since 4.8.0 .

markPoint.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of `path://`.

markPoint.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of  symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, `[0, '-50%']` means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markPoint.silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

markPoint.label.position.desc:
Label position.

**Followings are the options: **

+ [x, y]

Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box.
For example:
```js
// Absolute pixel values
position: [10, 10],
// Relative percentage
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

+ 'top'
+ 'left'
+ 'right'
+ 'bottom'
+ 'inside'
+ 'insideLeft'
+ 'insideRight'
+ 'insideTop'
+ 'insideBottom'
+ 'insideTopLeft'
+ 'insideBottomLeft'
+ 'insideTopRight'
+ 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

markPoint.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.


It is valid only when `position` is string value (like `'top'`、`'insideRight'`).

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

markPoint.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: [label rotation](bar-label-rotation).

markPoint.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: `[30, 40]` means move `30` horizontally and move `40` vertically.

markPoint.label.color.desc:
text color.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

the text fragment border type.

markPoint.label.rich.<style_name>.paddin.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

markPoint.label.rich.<style_name>.shadow.desc: Shadow color of the text block.
Show blur of the text block.
Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markPoint.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markPoint.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

color.



> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

markPoint.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

markPoint.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

markPoint.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

markPoint.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

markPoint.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

markPoint.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markPoint.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markPoint.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

See: [label rotation](bar-label-rotation).

markPoint.emphasis.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: `[30, 40]` means move `30` horizontally and move `40` vertically.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.c.desc:
text color.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.b.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
Border width of the text fragment.

the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.
Border radius of the text fragment.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.p.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.s.desc: Shadow color of the text block.
Show blur of the text block.
Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.w.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.h.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.t.desc:
Storke color of the text.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
Storke line width of the text.

Stroke line type of the text.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`textBorderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}
```

> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`textBorderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.
Shadow color of the text itself.
Shadow blue of the text itself.
Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.



> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.borderDashOffse.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.borderMiterLimi.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markPoint.blur.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markPoint.data.desc:
Data array for mark points, each of which is an object. Here are some ways to assign mark point position.
1. Assign coordinate according to container with [x](~series-lines.markPoint.data.x), [y](~series-lines.markPoint.data.y) attribute, in which pixel values and percentage are supported.



When multiple attributes exist, priority is as the above order.

**For example: **
```js
data: [

{
name: 'screen coordinate',
x: 100,
y: 100
}
]
```

markPoint.data.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markPoint.data.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markPoint.data.value.desc: Label value, which can be ignored.

markPoint.data.symbol.desc:
Symbol of .



Icon types provided by ECharts includes



`'circle'`, `'rect'`, `'roundRect'`, `'triangle'`, `'diamond'`, `'pin'`, `'arrow'`, `'none'`







It can be set to an image with `'image://url'` , in which URL is the link to an image, or `dataURI` of an image.


An image URL example:

```
'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
```

A `dataURI` example:

```
'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
```



Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via `'path://'` in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData) for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

```
'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
```

markPoint.data.symbolSize.desc: symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like `10`, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, `[20, 10]` means symbol width is `20`, and height is`10`.

markPoint.data.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of  symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when `symbol` is set to be `'arrow'` in `markLine`, `symbolRotate` value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markPoint.data.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of `path://`.

markPoint.data.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of  symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, `[0, '-50%']` means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markPoint.data.label.position.desc:
Label position.

**Followings are the options: **

+ [x, y]

Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box.
For example:
```js
// Absolute pixel values
position: [10, 10],
// Relative percentage
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

+ 'top'
+ 'left'
+ 'right'
+ 'bottom'
+ 'inside'
+ 'insideLeft'
+ 'insideRight'
+ 'insideTop'
+ 'insideBottom'
+ 'insideTopLeft'
+ 'insideBottomLeft'
+ 'insideTopRight'
+ 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

markPoint.data.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.


It is valid only when `position` is string value (like `'top'`、`'insideRight'`).

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

markPoint.data.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: [label rotation](bar-label-rotation).

markPoint.data.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: `[30, 40]` means move `30` horizontally and move `40` vertically.

If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.data.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

markPoint.data.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

markPoint.data.label.lineOverflow.desc:

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.borderColo.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.borderWidt.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.borderDash.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.borderRadi.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.shadowColo.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.shadowOffs.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.textBorder.desc:
Storke color of the text.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
Storke line width of the text.

Stroke line type of the text.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`textBorderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`textBorderType`

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.textShadow.desc: Shadow color of the text itself.
Shadow blue of the text itself.
Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

markPoint.data.emphasis.label.lineOverfl.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markPoint.data.emphasis.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.



> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

markPoint.data.emphasis.itemStyle.border.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

markPoint.data.emphasis.itemStyle.shadow.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```
Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.
Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markPoint.data.emphasis.itemStyle.opacit.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markPoint.animationThreshold.desc: Whether to set graphic number threshold to animation. Animation will be disabled when graphic number is larger than threshold.

markPoint.animationEasing.desc: Easing method used for the first animation. Varied easing effects can be found at [easing effect example](line-easing).

markPoint.animationDelayUpdate.blur.labe.desc: Whether to show label.

Label position.

**Followings are the options: **

+ [x, y]

Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box.
For example:
```js
// Absolute pixel values
position: [10, 10],
// Relative percentage
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

+ 'top'
+ 'left'
+ 'right'
+ 'bottom'
+ 'inside'
+ 'insideLeft'
+ 'insideRight'
+ 'insideTop'
+ 'insideBottom'
+ 'insideTopLeft'
+ 'insideBottomLeft'
+ 'insideTopRight'
+ 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

Distance to the host graphic element.


It is valid only when `position` is string value (like `'top'`、`'insideRight'`).

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: [label rotation](bar-label-rotation).
Whether to move text slightly. For example: `[30, 40]` means move `30` horizontally and move `40` vertically.

markLine.desc: Use a line in the chart to illustrate.

markLine.silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

markLine.symbol.desc: Symbol type at the two ends of the mark line. It can be an array for two ends, or assigned seperately. See [data.symbol](~series-lines.markLine.data.0.symbol) for more format information.

markLine.symbolSize.desc:
Symbol size at the two ends of the mark line. It can be an array for two ends, or assigned seperately.

**Attention: ** You cannot assgin width and height seperately as normal `symbolSize`.

markLine.precision.desc: Precision of marking line value, which is useful when displaying average value mark line.

markLine.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be:
+ `'start'` starting point of the line.
+ `'middle'` middle point of the line.
+ `'end'` ending point of the line.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: `'start'`, `'middle'`, `'end'`, `'insideStartTop'`, `'insideStartBottom'`, `'insideMiddleTop'`, `'insideMiddleBottom'`, `'insideEndTop'`, `'insideEndBottom'`.

`'insideMiddleBottom'` is the same as `'middle'`. Position is as the following chart.

The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with [label.distance](~series-.markLine.label.distance).

~[800x500](bar-markline&reset=1&edit=1)

markLine.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

markLine.label.color.desc:
text color.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

```js
}
```

markLine.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

markLine.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

markLine.label.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

markLine.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowC.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

markLine.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowB.desc: Show blur of the text block.

markLine.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowO.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markLine.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markLine.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.
